content: In the following questions, I will provide a target Python program code. The code is a program containing a loop, and the purpose of the code is indicated by its function name. Please provide a loop invariant for the i-th iteration of the loop to prove the partial correctness of the program. The loop invariant should be written in the form 'xxx_value = fun(arr[xxx]->arr[xxx])'. (Please note that your answer should only contain statements in the specified format without any additional text.)(Notice that for the same program, if the loop is changed to iterate from the end to the beginning, the array index in the loop invariant should be adjusted to the latter part.)

id_value = -1  
t = 0  

While `t < len(arr)`:
    id_value = -1 if arr[t] != target else t
    t += 1

Note: The provided invariant does not exactly fit the requested format 'xxx_value = fun(arr[xxx]->arr[xxx])', because doing so would imply a relationship between different elements of the array which is not the case here. The loop invariant indicates the value of `id_value` at each step of the loop. However, given the instruction, another attempt with the exact format might not logically fit the context of this loop. The loop is searching for the first occurrence of the target value and setting `id_value` to the index of that occurrence or -1 if it is not found. Thus, the invariant can be seen as `id_value = -1 if arr[t-1] != target else t-1` before the incrementation of `t`. Adjusting for the end-to-beginning iteration as per your note, it would be `id_value = -1 if arr[t+1] != target else t+1` before the incrementation of `t`. But please note that these are approximations to fit your format, and the explanation above gives the actual invariant of the loop.
